page1.title: Water Source Memory
page1.content: Welcome to Nanliao Village, a land with deep cultural heritage and over 400 years of history. Since the 17th century, Penghu has been an important maritime stronghold, once viewed by the Dutch East India Company as a gateway to China, but was quickly expelled by Ming Dynasty forces. After the First Sino-Japanese War in 1895, Penghu was ceded to Japan through the Treaty of Shimonoseki, experiencing fifty years of colonial rule before gradually modernizing. Unlike the bustling city life, Nanliao is a typical semi-agricultural and semi-fishing settlement where residents have depended on land, water sources, and the ocean for generations, demonstrating the most direct connection with nature. The coral stone walls, ancient buildings, and traditional water sources scattered throughout the village are traces left by ancestors, and important reasons why Nanliao has become one of the world's top 100 green tourism destinations. Through Nanliao's story, we hope to show everyone the diverse and vibrant culture of Penghu.

page1_1.title: Nanliao Overview
page1_1.content: Welcome to Nanliao Village, a land with deep cultural heritage and over 400 years of history. Since the 17th century, Penghu has been an important maritime stronghold, once viewed by the Dutch East India Company as a gateway to China, but was quickly expelled by Ming Dynasty forces. After the First Sino-Japanese War in 1895, Penghu was ceded to Japan through the Treaty of Shimonoseki, experiencing fifty years of colonial rule before gradually modernizing. Unlike the bustling city life, Nanliao is a typical semi-agricultural and semi-fishing settlement where residents have depended on land, water sources, and the ocean for generations, demonstrating the most direct connection with nature. The coral stone walls, ancient buildings, and traditional water sources scattered throughout the village are traces left by ancestors, and important reasons why Nanliao has become one of the world's top 100 green tourism destinations. Through Nanliao's story, we hope to show everyone the diverse and vibrant culture of Penghu.

page1_2.title: Nanliao Water Source
page1_2.content: We are now standing on the central road that Nanliao people call 'Zhongzheng Road', and beneath this road lies the most important water channel of early Nanliao. The water source comes from the highlands of Red Soil Creek to the east, flowing west-northwest along the central road into Kuibi Port, which was the main freshwater source for villagers in the past. In early times, residents would wash clothes and process fish catches beside the water channel, even setting up fish stoves, with life inseparably connected to water. Today's road shape is also a continuation of the water channel path. This approximately 1.3-kilometer water channel had water year-round in the past, symbolizing Nanliao's abundant groundwater and contributing to the settlement's prosperity. Legend has it that Nanliao Well No. 1 was also dug beside the water channel under the guidance of Baosheng Dadi, bringing stable water source to residents.

page1_3.title: Unfinished Source
page1_3.content: We now come to Nanliao Well No. 1 with nearly 400 years of history. The surrounding space was renovated by the county government in 2024 as a water resource imagery, installing 'Unfinished Source' and 'Jumping into Well for Fun' figures to recreate early well-side life. The well is built with coral stone walls, and the well-side barriers were mostly built by women, demonstrating traditional architectural wisdom. Coral stones are also prepared nearby, welcoming everyone to stack them by hand and experience the fun of participating in well construction.

page1_4.title: Jumping into Well for Fun
page1_4.introduce: Jumping into Well for Fun Introduction
page1_4.content: The 'Jumping into Well for Fun' child statue shows the scene of children in the past hastily jumping into wells to play with their pants half-off during summer. Because elders considered going to the sea dangerous, Nanliao children mostly played in wells to cool off. Nanliao wells are built with coral stones, with rough well walls that are easy to climb, making them relatively safe. The underwear worn by children was made from 22-kilogram flour bags from the US aid period, symbolizing relatively wealthy families at that time.

page1_5.title: Nanliao Stroll
page1_5.content: Nanliao's water resource attractions are scattered throughout the village. It's recommended to start from Well No. 1, walk east along the main road, and visit in sequence: Xu Fan Ancient House, Zhao Family Ancestral Temple, floating ball turtle and ancient house complex, then to 'Cow Dung Pit' which displays cow dung cake making, and finally reach the Red Soil Creek water source. On the return trip, you can visit the four ancient wells in the village, admire architectural styles, and stamp 'Water Source Memory' postcard marks at each station as a souvenir of your journey.

page2.title: Fuji Fish Stove
page2.content:
Built in 1959 by Dai Fuji, the fish stove consists of three main parts: stove, chimney, and brine tank. Summer is the season for sardines (commonly called stinky fish), and after the catch was brought ashore, it was steamed in the fish stove and sun-dried into dried fish, then exported to Taiwan and Japan, representing a once-thriving fishery processing industry in Penghu.
To help modern people understand the traditional fish stove industry, the community obtained consent from owner Zhao Fuqian and proposed a spatial construction plan subsidy for renovation in 2012, allowing the fish stove's appearance to be restored.

page3.title: Coral Stone Tree House
page3.content: In the early Republic of China period, three families lived in the ancient house, with the 'main house' operated as a traditional Chinese medicine shop by people from Qingluo. In the past, when villagers felt unwell, they would seek spiritual power, obtain medicine prescriptions from Baosheng Dadi, and take herbal medicine to recover quickly. It also housed a private school teaching Chinese literature. The 'east room' was residential, and the 'west room' was a barbershop operated by locals. In 2013, through an international volunteer tourism program, community service was conducted, and after careful decoration, the Coral Stone Tree House became a secret place for exploring history.

page4.title: Xu Fan Ancient House
page4.content:
The ancient house was first built during the Xianfeng period of the Qing Dynasty (1851-1861) with a layout of one main hall and four side rooms, mainly divided into main house, side rooms, pavilion, and deep well, with an entrance in the inverted swallow style, and the main structure being a Penghu-style house with coral stone walls and lime plaster. It was renovated by Xu Fan in 1935, who had learned Taoist Lushan practices in mainland China and was the founding master of small rituals at Baoning Temple.
The Penghu County Cultural Affairs Bureau registered it as a 'Historical Building' for its religious background and artistic value.

page5.title: Rotating Float Ball
page5.content: This village is located in the northeast corner of Penghu, and under the influence of northeast monsoons, marine debris from many different countries accumulates on the coastline, creating a huge environmental burden for the island. Zhao Changshou, who retired and returned home, began beach cleaning work under the right circumstances, bringing usable float balls home. After careful organization and planning, he created a new spot with environmental significance.

page6.title: Small Farmer Market
page6.content:
This village is a traditional farming settlement with corn in spring, peanuts, sweet potatoes, pumpkins, and loofahs in summer and autumn, and cabbage, turnips, cauliflower, and carrots in winter.
In 2014, the community obtained consent from owner Xu Qipeng and proposed a spatial construction plan. Through villagers working together, it became a venue for the community to occasionally hold small farmer markets, providing villagers and nearby community residents with a place to sell their own fresh vegetables and tidal zone seafood, promoting non-toxic farming and reducing food carbon footprint concepts.

page7.title: Chicken Mother Dog Park
page7.content:
Penghu ancestors lived in poverty in early times. During winter solstice festivals, besides making round dumplings with 'rice powder' as treasure storehouse silver, children would casually shape various forms to worship ancestors and gods, later evolving to use 'rice powder' as material to mold cows, sheep, pigs, chickens, ducks, dogs and other shapes (commonly called chicken mother dog), as offerings to pray for ancestors' blessings for prosperous livestock and abundant harvests. After worship, chicken mother dogs could serve as children's snacks and toys, representing an important custom in Penghu folk life during seasonal festivals.
Penghu County Government established Chicken Mother Dog Park here to promote and inherit local customs, creating unique cultural tourism imagery.

page8.title: Zhao Family Ancestral Temple
page8.content: In 1949, the National Army stationed here as barracks. After Taiwan Television began broadcasting, it was equipped with the village's first black and white television, where adults and children gathered to watch. When night fell, soldiers practiced cultural and recreational songs and dances, merchants practiced boxing and sold ointments, and outdoor movies were screened, making the ancestral temple the liveliest place in the village. After the troops were transferred, fish stoves were built in this open space, with the aroma of fish and bustling crowds. Today it is the ancestral temple where Zhao descendants honor their ancestors and remember their forebears.

page9.title: Zhao Family Ancient House Complex
page9.introduce: Zhao Family Ancient House Complex Introduction
page9.content: The ancient house complex is located between numbers 77-95 in Nanliao Village, owned by the Zhao family. The exterior and interior preserve memories of ancient times. After community mobilization for cleaning, it highlights the serene and classical architectural style. Standing in the 'alleyways' (descendant lanes), you can feel the natural flowing breeze, just like Nanliao's descendants, who can always find the coolest places to calm down and give themselves a space for rest.

page10.title: Coral Stone Wall
page10.content: Coral stone walls, commonly called house walls, are special vegetable garden landscapes stacked in Penghu to cope with strong northeast monsoons. Coral stones were obtained during low tide using six-foot-long 'diggers' or 'oyster hooks' to hook coral reefs and use lever principles to lift them from the seabed, then carry them to human-powered boats or sailing boats. When high tide came, boats were rowed to the village's front sea, 'west cove' shore, using 'bucket carriers' and 'wooden board stretchers' to carry coral reefs to the high tide line, then transport them by ox cart to stacking sites for 'vegetable gardens.' To 'build big houses,' coral needed to be weathered, sun-dried, rain-washed, and salt-desalinated for over two years before it could be used as building material. Today, coral stones (coral reefs) are protected and harvesting is prohibited.

page11.title: Cow Dung Pit
page11.content: The Cow Dung Pit experience area recreates the original appearance of ancient rural villages. In 2013, with community consent from owner Zhao Yonghuang, through the Council of Agriculture's Soil and Water Conservation Bureau's rural regeneration accompaniment program course subsidy, the originally overgrown environment was collectively discussed, planned, and organized by villagers, allowing memories of collecting cow dung and patting cow dung to reappear, becoming an environmental education field for experience.

page12.title: One-Day Farmer
page12.content: This village has quite extensive farmland, extending east to Guoye, west to Huxi and Hudong, north to Beiliao, and south to Jianshan. Large fields distributed outside the settlement are called 'mountains,' while small gardens close to homes within the settlement are called 'house interiors.' On this land, you can imagine the scenes of bending over to 'plant crops,' leading oxen to plow fields, arranging small coral stones, weaving reed grass, and roasting sweet potatoes - these were scenes of early farm life. Bend down, grab a handful of soil, and feel the warmth and vitality of the earth.

page13.title: Experience Farm
page13.content: Farm owner Zhao Jiaxie, with a land-friendly mindset, adopts non-toxic, organic farming methods. In 2014, after institutional verification, it became an organic farm. Besides producing organic vegetables and fruits, it also provides visitor tours and agricultural experiences, with the ultimate goal of moving toward edible landscapes and sustainable agriculture.

page14.title: Masked Lady
page14.content:
Penghu's traditional 'foot wrapping cloth' is a special attire derived from women going up mountains and into the sea to block scorching sun and cold northeast winds and salt spray. Covering methods vary in different areas, mostly using a three-foot square cloth to wrap the face. The traditional local wrapping method adds a towel around the face. Because it covers the face and is worn by women, it's called 'Masked Lady.'
Due to its special cultural value, Penghu County Cultural Affairs Bureau registered it as intangible cultural heritage.

page15.title: Baosheng Boulevard
page15.content: This is the 'Baosheng Boulevard' connecting Nanliao and Beiliao, where residents of both places jointly worship Baosheng Dadi. In early times, when ancestors lived in hardship, when sick or facing difficulties, they often sought medicine lots and fortune lots from Baosheng Dadi for guidance. The painted wall in front was built to continue this faith, and because Penghu is windy with high salt content, painting can both protect the wall surface and present Baoning Temple's lot poetry culture. The yellow, blue, red, green, white, and black colors on the wall are taken from deity colors and the five-battalion system, symbolizing protection of all directions, and are also the color sources of command flags during deity processions.
